Eleazar Wheelock was the one
Who had the first library

Quest20.Description: Explores the history of Hanover’s libraries – and mysterious moving buildings!
Quest20.Clue1: To get there: This Quest starts in the middle of the Dartmouth College green.  Take 91 to exit 13, travel east across the Connecticut River, and up the hill on West Wheelock.  The green is at the top of the hill on your left.
Quest20.Clue8:
Turn left and go east straight on your way
Past a new place to park don't be tempted to stay!
Crossing beyond to Maloney's right there
Then cross once again and stop!  We are WHERE?
Yes, in 1975 it happened once again
all of  those books were moved to a different spot!
Quest20.Clue6:
Cross West Wheelock.  Go right We're almost there
And the mystery solved about the house that went WHERE?
Keep going, keep looking, and follow your noses.
Open your eyes wide-can you smell the roses?
Go in (if it is open) four columns you've seen before
Two located on either side of the door.
Quest20.Clue4:
Our mystery will be solved later in the day,
But first we go off in another way.
Walk north to an architectural treasure
Whose stones are too huge to measure.
Be sure to count the arches all
Before you turn to the four-columned hall.
Two Dartmouth libraries side by side.

From where you park go to the green.
Meet in the middle where a clock is seen.
Then turn to the east.  Walk to a building tall
It is on a corner and its name is Reed Hall.

To this place, the Howe Library, 
that we enjoy a whole lot!
Go down the stairs and around the back, 
looking for the bicycle rack.

Open the hinge and you will squeal with glee!
Quest20.Title: Libraries of Hanover
Quest20.Clue7:

While a flower shop now, it used to be a library HOWE!
Now back to the corner, and stroll south to where awnings abound
Dartmouth, Ledyard, Wheelock are names to be found.
Stop at the ivy-covered building in the middle
Then go to the second light to soon solve this riddle.
Quest20.Clue5:
One of columns to view with pride 
The other one with a weather-vane tower
That chimes for you at every hour.
Proceed west.  Four brick buildings you will see.
Then walk south: at the corner an eatery.

Two red brick buildings sit side by side.
A little law office, and in "1828"
Governor Pingree resided.

Travel approx. 1 mile to get to Hartford Village.  The Quest begins at the Hartford Historical Society, 1461 Maple Street.
Quest112.Clue8:
This hotel welcomed strangers to our town.
Now enter the store and ask the store clerk
Where your treasure box can be found.
Quest112.Clue6:
Follow the path back to the road called "Ferry Boat Crossing."
On the road take a left. (I don't mean to be so bossy.)
Just before several houses, take the small path heading up to the right.
Climb diagonally up the hill until the town is back in sight.
Quest112.Clue4:
Go across the road to a sign that says "Ferry Boat Crossing."
Go down the hill to a pile of rocks. (Please-no tossing!)
Once an old covered bridge ended right here,
But due to spring flooding, the iron bridge up above appeared.
Quest112.Clue2:
Stand in front of the Hartford Historical Society, and
Your Quest will begin.
When this house was first built in 1915
An undertaker lived within.
Quest112.Title: White River Village
Quest112.Clue7:
Now go carefully across the road to the Elk with the star.
Head south and cross Park Street to a store for your car.
On this spot-right where you standóonce stood the Pease Hotel.
An 1889 fire swept through the building making everyone yell!
Quest112.Clue5:
Walk 45 paces upstream, then turn left to the river.
Stroll down to the banks. Don't fall in or you'll shiver!
Look across to a stone wall where a dam used to be,
Making power for many busy factories.

Quest93.Clue21:
Along the way, go to a white pillar on your right (a memorial) just this one more.
In memory to those taken captive by the Indians in 1754.
Now facing west go down the stone steps you came up.
The treasure is where the pine tree leaves the earth.
Shouldn't it be "one" instead of "some" then?
Quest93.Clue5:
Keep heading south.  Do you hear the sound of a bell?  
Is it the church or the brick house next to it that would ring so well?
It is the brick house that in 1772 was built as a one- room schoolhouse.  This is the oldest schoolhouse in Charlestown and it held 40 students, the youngest learning their ABC's and the oldest algebra.
Quest93.Clue17:
Hurry now, let's not be late.
Now inside bear right at the first fork.  Then left at the second fork onto a dirt roadway to some stone steps.  Go up the steps and walk straight and narrow until adjacent to the second oak tree off to your left.
Quest93.Title: Fort 4's Past
Quest93.Clue12:
At the next crosswalk you will do just that; and come to some grand trees upon a large lawn.  Can you identify these large evergreens?  Let's hope they never have to be sawn.
South you roamed the first part of this quest, now traveling north I think would be best.
Quest93.Clue4:
Start at the Fire station and head south toward town.
The very first house on the left is where you are bound.
This is the site of the Johnson's cabin. They were captured by Indians in 1754. 
They returned to Charlestown after a ransom was paid.
The original cabin is hidden underneath the modern exterior.
Quest93.Clue9: It had a sign with a beehive and bees on it, just like the Beehive Tavern of Philadelphia.  I'll mention here as a last note, this place is haunted by two ghosts!  (Oh I almost forgot to say, so was the first house along the way.)
Quest93.Clue19:
The people from the fort have been here a long time but so has something that is living.
Can you guess what it may be?  Look ahead at the edge of the woods.
My goodness it's a huge sycamore tree!  How many times do your arms go around?
18 feet the diameter was found.  Just imagine how long this tree has been standing here.
Quest93.Clue14:
Keep traveling north along Main.  Go to place you would visit if your tooth had a pain.
Moses Willard, an occupant of the fort, built this house.
Later, two brothers bought it in 1839.
They married two sisters and split the house in two, each living in half.
Quest93.Clue3: Please park in back of the fire station, well out of the way.
Quest93.Clue8: Travel south yet once again, to the site of what was the Walker Tavern where you were once able to go right in.  This stone house was the home of Mary Walker whom was the great granddaughter of an original grantee of  # 4.  The "stone cottage" as it is commonly called, used to be the Walker Tavern.
Quest93.Clue16:
You will come to a street named after the direction you were just heading.
Now head north along the street named East, you will come to a cemetery I am betting.
Turn right through the first gate.
Quest93.Clue20:
History we have discovered and trees of many year.
It's almost time to find our treasure, which is very near.
Facing the tree turn right and head down the road.
Be careful not to step on a toad!
Quest93.Clue11:
Now look for a brick house as you journey along and I'll tell you of a poltergeist's song.
This house underwent re-construction to return it to its original state.  It was then that the owners heard the ghost.  It banged boards together and slammed doors.  When the re-construction was done, the ghosts' noises disappeared.
Quest93.Clue22:
Insert period
Should be "ghost's"
Out of curiosity-careful how?  With the construction?  With his hammer?
Insert "a"
George suggests using the term "double-stoned slab" instead, as there is another "Moses Willard" stone near the first oak tree.
Do we need to be PC?
Quest93.Description: Find the original site of the Fort as you learn about Charlestown’s rich history.
Quest93.Clue2: Upon entering the village, look for the fire station which is the first building on the left.  Enter the driveway only just beyond the station building as this is a one-way driveway.
Quest93.Clue7: The library holds a lot of interesting things, including a carved wooden eagle (seen from the side door) and some of Charles Hoyt's plays (one of only five in existence).
Quest93.Clue18:
You are looking for the gravestone of Moses and Susannah Willard, who were killed by Indians June 16th of 1756.  Pay your respects to these fort settlers buried here.
Now look straight ahead, slightly to your left, for a chalice standing high in the sky.
It is the Johnson's burial spot, also settlers of the fort.
Quest93.Clue13:
Onward to a place where you can sleep and eat while resting your very weary feet.
Now a bed & breakfast this house was built by Phineas Stevens in 1752.  
He was very careful while building this house, for Indians captured him as a youth.
Quest93.Clue1: To Get There:  From Exit 7 off I-91, travel east on Route 11.  At the intersection of Routes 11 & 12, take Route 12 south towards Charlestown Village.
Quest93.Clue6:
Continue down the sidewalk quite a ways, until a pizza parlor comes into your gaze.
You could stop in to have a bite to eat, but when you're done go back outside and cross the street.  The place you should find yourself to be is in front of the Silsby Public Library.
Quest93.Clue15:
Keep going toward a brick building called Dan's, you can buy everything here from cards to pans.  The street next to this is Perry Ave., travel up it if the treasure you want to have.
On the side of this building you will see, a mural dedicated to Charlestown's past history.
Continue to the end of this street.
Quest93.Clue10:
The next house south that is on your right, is Fort #4's original site!
At your back is a stone with a plaque. Go over and read a little Fort history.
Now travel south to house #304.  Stop here and of history you'll learn more.  Hidden by bushes in the back of this house is a well that is thought to have been used by the fort.

Quest109.Clue5:
Just to compare, walk 14 paces (if you dare)
And to your right will be a maple tree of a different type.
Its leaf edges are smooth. Its 5 lobes make many Vs.
But it is because of the syrup that it makes
That we call this one a "sugar" maple tree.
Quest109.Title: Hurricane Forest
Quest109.Clue12:
But your Quest turns around and
You must now head back downstream
To the previous fork where you now take a left
And head across a bridge with your Questing team.
Quest109.Clue4:
Continue clockwise until you enter the woods.
Stop at 6 gray boulders and then you should
Turn 180 degrees and find the maple tree
Which has split into three.
Notice its leaves with coarsely toothed lobes.
We call it "Red" because of its autumn glow.
Quest109.Clue9:
Notice the direction that all of the trees fell.
They were blown to the North-Northwest...
A sure sign of a hurricane which comes at us
From the South Southeast at its best.
Quest109.Clue14:
On your right you will find a white pine,
One with a very large trunk.
This trunk splits into two curly stalks-
And a good place to find a chipmunk.
Quest109.Clue3:
Walk clockwise around the pond, and in 60 paces
You will see a house in the water of all places.
A habitat for hobbits? A shelter for lambs?
Noóa place where water is released from the dam.
Quest109.Clue8:
The mounds we call pillows and the holes are cradles.
And in this particular site
Several pillows and cradles reveal that trees were blown down,
Together by a force of wind of a great height.
Quest109.Clue16:
Between its trunks you will find your treasure,
And when you've finished there is no need to measure.
For the quickest way back to your car
Is to continue northeast until you hit the tar.
Quest109.Clue11:
As you proceed and come to a fork a left you'll take.
Follow a brook upstream to your next stop: A stone wall (no mistake).
Go 25 paces to a bench made of trees
And rest while you think awhile.
From here you could choose to explore these woods
And hike for many a mile.
Quest109.Clue2:
To begin your Quest go between two fences
To a place with a map; here one can be quite pensive.
This reservoir was named after Major David Wright.
From here you jus might see a heron take flight.
This pond was built to supply water to town.
They used no pipes. It just flowed over the ground.
Quest109.Description: ID trees – while tracking the Hurricane of ’38.
Quest109.Clue7:
If you look to the ground, mounds you will see.
These mark where the roots and trunks of trees used to be.
And behind each mound is a slight hole in the ground.
This is the place where roots were before the tree came down.
Quest109.Clue13:
Admire the white pine stand
While continuing on the footpath.
Now stop just before the second bridge
And your next clue will require a little math.
Quest109.Clue1: To get there: From White River Junction, follow Route 5 south.  Go under 2 highway overpasses. Beyond the second one turn right onto Wright Reservoir Road.  Go 0.5 miles and park at the turnout on your left.  Walk uphill 50 feet to begin your Quest. Note: Please bring a compass.
Quest109.Clue6:
Continue on the path until you reach the next plateau.
And notice a small ridge to the south as you go.
When that ridge ends you are near your next stop:
A birch tree on the left with blue on the trunk-not it's top.
Quest109.Clue15:
Cross the bridge now and on your right you will find
Five rows of log benches no beaver did grind.
Take a rest on the bench positioned first on the right.
Ah, we have nature's beauty in our sight.
Look to the south for a two-trunked tree
That branches into six (that's 2 times 3).
Quest109.Clue10:
This wind was fierce, the rain caused flooding.
Chaos and destruction it did create,
For this was the storm of all storms in New England-
The great "Hurricane of 1938."

Keep walking, eyes open, for chew marks and stumps

Quest101.Clue9:

Where the pond is held back is a wall of debris
Built by the inhabitants who homes we now know.
Quest101.Club13:
Two plus four zeros years ago
Glacier's carved this boggy bowl.
A glacial ice chunk stayed and melted.
We call this place a "kettle hole."
Quest101.Clue3:
As you walk straight ahead you will view wonderful treesó
A garden of pine, hemlock, and birch.
It could have been houses on lot after lot
But Ester saw better things out on a search.
Quest101.Clue8:
Fifty-four more steps forward, then spy to the right
(Two hundred degrees to be most precise!)
Another lodge of our friend Castor Canadensis.
And a sign revealing beaver's built here at least twice.
Quest101.Club10:
Cross the bridge, and follow the shaded path
Past spruce and fir, hemlock and white pine.
On the forest floor, note the cradles and pillows.
At "Davis Path" turn right towards Observation Blinds.
Quest101.Club15:
Out of the bog, the trail goes up and down
Ancient glaciers molded these small mounds
Straight ahead spy yet another beaver lodge

Quest101.Club17:
Your quest is done, but look for more lodges.
There are at least 2-and many species of duck.
If you're patient, these all will come into view.
What else can we say but this: Good Luck!
Quest101.Clue2:
Esther Currier knew this land well.
She envisioned a site of nature and fun.
Our Quest starts at the gate as you walk down the path
To a haven of beauty where animals run.
Quest101.Clue7:
Head back to the main trail, then onward one hundred steps
To beaver's former residence, built of mud and old chew.
There, a tree like a chimney rises up high
Taking in the still water with reflective hues.
Quest101.Club12:
Immediate left past the number eight.
Do not - No, do not! - go on to the T.
Towards Marsh Point your path snakes
Please cross on the boardwalk carefully.

Quest101.Clue1: To get there:  Take I-89 to Exit 11.  Take Route 11 east towards New London, NH.  Travel 2.6 miles.  A cemetery will appear on your left and a small parking area on your right.  Turn right into the parking lot for the Esther Currier Wildlife Sanctuary.
Quest101.Clue6:
Look out to the Magical Wetland and see
Reflections of trees, of clouds and of sky.
Standing dead trunks, called snags, pierce this scene
A reminder of times when this setting was dry.
Quest101.Club14:
You're walking on a sphagnum sponge,
Sheep laurel grows on this moist ground.
Look for tamarack large and small!
The only deciduous conifer around!

Quest44.Clue6:
Go over the bridge, enjoy the view, cross the street, you have to!

Quest15.Clue21:
In 1892 the building in front of you was called
The Grafton Cooperative Cheese Factory.
Dairy farmers brought their milk here and got cheese in return.
In 1912, The Cooperative burned down.
Quest15.Clue5:
At the top of the little hill, take a right
And go until the tubing hill is in sight.
The pond below was made by men not long ago
 It is used for wildlife, skating, and making snow.
Quest15.Clue17:
HINT: The word begins with an "S"
The name of the town that you see is important too. Use the third letter in the name of the town.
Quest15.Title: Grafton Ponds
Quest15.Clue12:
Keep moving north.  
You will see two trees in the middle of a three-pointed fork.
As you move down the trail, note the blackberry bushes everywhere.  
They are a sign that this place was cleared 
For sheep farming at one time.
Quest15.Clue23:
Congratulations! You've finished our quest!  
Write all of the letters below in the order that you found them.
Quest15.Clue4:
Start in the parking lot. Go up the steep slope, 
This trail was a logging road a long time ago.
Around 1860, Grafton had three lumber mills
So lots of timber was cut down from these hills.
Quest15.Clue19:
The stones are big and that's how we know
The field was used for grazing animals, instead of to grow
Vegetables.  If the stones were small then we would have found
That they were probably dug out of the ground.
Quest15.Clue14:
Keep moving north.
There are trails that branch out leading east and west.
Don't take them.
Notice that the trail is wider then it used to be. 
This is because of the invention of a new style of ski.  
You'll know you are on the right trail if you see an uprooted tree.
(Tree is on the right)
Quest15.Clue3:
Welcome to Grafton Ponds! This area was created around fifteen years ago because
The Old Tavern at Grafton wanted their guests to have something recreational to do.
Quest15.Clue8:
There are a lot of animals that live in these woods
There are woodchuck, deer, bear, and raccoons.
As you move down the trail, look for a trail sign.
The sign will be on your right.
Quest15.Clue16:
This property used to be owned by a man named Ed McWilliams. 
This spot may be where he used to see his sheep grazing peacefully.
Look in the distance for the two pointy towers.  
You will need the fifth letter of the official name of these architectural features.
Quest15.Clue20:
Look at the beautiful field and take a rest 
Head down the hill, there is not much left. 
Follow the River to the covered bridge.  
You need to find out the name of the river below.
The first letter of the name of this river is the last clue that you need!
Quest15.Clue11:
The third and seventh letters are the same and you need to remember this letter.
Continue past the leaning tree
Who's two trunks come together in the shape of a V.
Quest15.Clue22:
And for a while there was no cheese in this town.
In 1967, this place was rebuilt
With the friendly help of Ed Mcwilliams.
Now, this world-renowned factory of cheese
Holds your treasure, so go in and buy yourself a Gold treat!
Quest15.Description: This Quest along Grafton trails can be walked, biked or skied.
Quest15.Clue2: Cross the bridge, turn right after the bridge, and follow the signs to Grafton.  In the heart of Grafton, turn left just before the Tavern, and proceed until you see a sign that says Grafton Ponds.
Quest15.Clue7:
When you're done at the first stop
Turn around and go straight up the hill
No humans have lived here and this we know
Because there is no evidence of old cellar holes
Quest15.Clue18:
Off to the field and look for a few birdhouses as you go.
To get to the field, go down the trail and take a right. 
There are  stonewalls that surround this field.
Quest15.Clue13:
Some of the trees that you see
Are used to make a famous Vermont product.
Remember the first letter of this sweet treat?
Quest15.Clue24:
If you go into the cheese factory and ask for your treasure box,
They will ask you for a password.  The letters that you have written above 
Will spell your password.
Quest15.Clue1: To get there: Take route 121 west to Saxons River. Past the post office there will be a fork in the road.  Take a left and keep on going until you get to a little town with a general store.
Quest15.Clue6:
Look for the small building down by the pond. It was originally set up as a warming hut and picnic site.  Now it is also used to rent skis and sell food. What type of building is this? 
Hint:  This type of building ends with an "N", 
but you need to remember the letter, which it begins!
Quest15.Clue15:
Make sure you stay to the right of the big oak tree.
The bark has many deep ridges with flat areas in between. 
Take the NEXT left and move towards the village over look.
Quest15.Clue10:
Don't go down that trail, but read the sign for your next clue.
The sign says that this trail is used for something specific to do.

Quest106.Clue5: The competition has eliminated many trees to the point where today-in 2002-there are about 2,000 - 3,000 trees per acre.  But by the time the trees here have matured in 2060 or 2080 only 150 trees per acre will remain.
Quest106.Clue17: TO GET BACK TO THE PARKING LOT: Continue up the path. Soon you will arrive at a very large, steep hill. The path becomes narrower. If you walk up the steep path, you will be back at the Ray School.
Quest106.Title: Storr's Pond
Quest106.Clue12: Pass the snack bar on the left and soon you will come to a small, wooden footbridge.  Walk to the middle of the bridge and you will see a rock-bedded stream; tadpoles and water striders jump about and may be seen.
Quest106.Clue4: Look straight ahead and enter a pine needle-covered forest floor.  Look above and all around you and you shall see a stand of white pine trees. Look a little closer and you may discover black cherry, red maple, yellow birch, poplar, white ash, brown ash, and maybe even a basswood.
Quest106.Clue9: This is a drainage canal that controls runoff from the road. In front of you there should be 8 large logs all lined up as seats. You are now at campground "A" of Storr's Pond.
Quest106.Clue14: Choose the one not shallow and do not stand still. Follow the narrow footpath that shall lead you eventually back to the great blue walls of the Ray School. Keep an eye out for garter snakes and red squirrels that may dart across your path.
Quest106.Clue3: Continue down the path until you spy a dark, wooden, colonial house.  Go to the maple tree to the left of the house.  From there, face the wire fencing that keeps "Shamrock."  Take a moment to learn of the great deeds he performs.
Quest106.Clue8: At this point you should be in a small clearing in the forest.  Seek a small, fern-lined path immediately to your left. Follow a dip and then up a bit until you come to a road in front of you. Come to a stop at a rock-filled ditch.
Quest106.Clue16: Here, the path diverges; take the small path to your right. Find a grand hemlock tree swaying so gracefully. If you look carefully under the branches you may discover an informative treasure.
Quest106.Clue11: Take a right and pause at the swings. Find a seat and swing away. Enjoy the views of maples in front of you. Mosey past the swings and soon you will arrive at Storr's Smores. You can grab a quick snack to quench your Questing hunger!
Quest106.Clue2: Upon arriving at the Ray School back parking lot by the gym, look straight ahead and take the tree-lined trail cut out from the field.  Look to your left and look to the right, and see Queen Anne's lace and Buttercups bow their heads gracefully in the breeze.
Quest106.Description: Enjoy Storr’s pond and environs; footpaths, forest and park land.
Quest106.Clue7: The path diverges: take a right and you shall see a U-shaped tree with a yellow circular marker.  Follow the path until you reach a massive, mossy, decaying log. Explore it delicately, so as not to disrupt the termites and beetles that make their home in the detritus matter.
Quest106.Clue18: Take an immediate right and follow the building until you are returned safe and sound to the parking lot from which you began your Quest.
Quest106.Clue13: Walk back across the bridge the way you came and follow the paved path to the left to yet another parking lot. Traverse across the parking area until you reach a basketball court. Past the courts are two trails, one steep and the other shallow.
Quest106.Clue1: To get there: Travel north on  Route 10 to Reservoir Road.  Turn and travel east on Reservoir Road until you see the Bernice A. Ray School.  Turn left into the school parking lot and park.  The Quest begins by the entrance to the gym.
Quest106.Clue6:
As you walk through this stand, see if you can find trees that have recently died, as well as trees that have been dead for a long time.
Continue down the steep hill until you arrive at an intersection.
Quest106.Clue15: The footpath widens gradually so that two people may walk side by side. Upon arriving at a clearing in the woods you will spy two birdhouses to your left. If you are lucky you may see a chickadee dining.
Quest106.Clue10: Bear right down a paved road. Once you have reached the bottom of the road, there will be tennis courts and a pool to your right. Go to the parking lot nearest to the pond and look to the left and you will see a white billboard standing so lonely. Go and visit this board. Here you shall learn of the pondís water quality.

Quest9.Clue5:
Enfield village is your first destination,
Hiking or biking, get on with exploration!
Head to the right or, with a compass, go West!
All aboard this historical Rail Trail Quest!
Quest9.Title: Enfield Rail
Quest9.Clue12:
The next bridge makes us stop and wonder:
Who built this so cars take turns going under?
The Shakers built the big bridge across the lake
To get to the rail depot without effort great.
Did they tunnel under here and thus this bridge?
Give a friendly wave to those who way give.
Quest9.Clue4:
Whistle stops and train rides are long gone,
Victims of highways and air travel throngs.
Out of sight are rotting ties and rusty rails,
Now there is gravel and the Northern Rail Trail.
Quest9.Clue9:
The trail up ahead appears flat and straight,
But look to the sides, you are gaining height.
You're on top of what's called an embankment 
Built for the railroad's advancement.
Quest9.Clue14:
Upon these walls are etched names and dates,
By workers whose sweat this passage did make.
At the end of the pass on the left is a rock,
Behind "1853" you will find the Quest box!
Quest9.Clue3:
In eighteen hundred and forty seven,
Enfield folk thought they'd gone to heaven.
To this depot they and their cargo could now roll
To ride the brand new Northern Railroad.
Quest9.Clue8:
On the left is Mascoma Lake, long and deep,
Named after an ancient Squakheag Indian Chief.
His village was in Mass., far away in those days,
But his tribe hunted this far North, anyway.
Quest9.Clue11:
To the right of this bank, is a rich habitat,
A wetland home for many a duck, in fact.
Explore a little and you may see
A frog, a turtle, a heron...lucky thee!
Quest9.Clue2: Take the first left onto Depot Street. Park at the end of Depot St. in the parking lot to the left of the red building. This building is the old Enfield railroad depot, but now houses the town ambulances. Please make sure not to block the emergency vehicles in any way.
Quest9.Description: Walking through space to mars, you will see stars and martians. There is no comparing the greenness of the aliens, and their work on mars creates an awesome place to explore. Have fun going back in time and changing the past, or seeing the ultimite end of human life from a distance. It's all fun and games when it comes to the this marian trip. This is a fake description
Quest9.Clue7:
Next stop is the bridge over Mascoma River,
The bridge or the rapids might make you quiver.
Instead think back to how water helped fill a hole
Left behind by a glacier, before humans strolled.
Quest9.Clue13:
The Quest is over, when rock walls appear.
"Ledges Pass" they are called, the end is near.
Two gangs of workers, forty men, they say,
Took a year to carve this cut, with nary a stay.
Gas or steam engines were not yet the rule,
Hand drills and explosives their only tools.
Quest9.Clue1: To get there: Take I-89 to Exit 17. Take Rte. 4 east 4 miles to Enfield. Take the second right past the Enfield Garage (High St.) just as Rte. 4 makes a sharp left into town. At the first stop sign, go straight through the intersection.
Quest9.Clue6:
Before the railroad came, this area, it is said,
Was mostly farms and a few homesteads.
The train was a magnet for prosperity,
Thus the shops, mills and village that you see.
Quest9.Clue15: Questers please note: At the far end of the pass, there is a trail that leads to the shore of the lake. Once you are on the trail, you are on the private property of Mr. Earl Farnham. Please respect his beautiful property, and be aware that you are passing at your own risk.
Quest9.Clue10:
This area was once marsh, soggy and wet,
With no place to run a train through...yet.
Rail workers piled dirt high across this wet spot,
Until it was set and their backs were in knots.

Quest97.Clue12:
The sign at the top of the hill has a digit that stands
Fir the same number of fingers you have on one hand.
The downed white birch marks the last hilltop tale.
Look closer! It's covered with lots of turkey tails.
Quest97.Clue25:
Backtrack to the large flat rock; a perfect place to rest and roost
Scan the woods to your left, until you see a web of roots.
Break trail to this mysterious place
Walk gently and look down; you may find an orange newt's face
Quest97.Clue11:
As you approach the stone steps, look to the right.
I used to be a tall tree-now I'm shortened in height.
Insects and fungus eat me for food.
They need me for nourishment when in the mood.
Nearby the steps find another tree.
With this one what is the mystery?
It's roots are eroded and show off like bones.
These make ideal spots for chipmunk homes.
Quest97.Clue24:
Walk to the mowed grass and feel the sun shining on your face

Survey the land where mouse eats seeds and fox eats mouse
Up and down the food chain sun and water matter most.
Quest97.Clue10:
Here at the "Y" head up the hill.
Keep following the trail and observe as you will.
You'll see holes in trees that are called cavities
And fungus growing, too, on the trees that are diseased.
Quest97.Clue9:
Along the path twin pines mark your way.
You wish you could linger there all day.
Take 22 steps to the start of a high mushroom trail.
Look to your left for the path, you can't fail.
Quest97.Clue23:
Continue to the wild field past goldenrod and milkweed
Refurbished every year by many dispersed seeds.
Alive with busy insects on a hot summer day
Dragonflies, wasps and crickets go along their way.
Quest97.Clue7:
Here the land is low and flat.
Pine needles make a lovely mat.
The hemlock forest is there if you seek.
All it takes is just a little peek.
Quest97.Clue22:
Pass two logs with hollow centers
Home to a mole escaping hunting owl dangers?
Daddy mole, watch out!
You better protect your little mole sprout.
Quest97.Clue5:
Up to the double trees (pine and oak) you should go
But not into the water with your toe!
A snapping turtle lives there all year long,
This C.R.E.A. land is where he belongs.
Quest97.Clue21:
Ahead a "cradle and pillow" upon the ground to rest your head
Or for a tiny chipmunk it could make a cozy bed.
This tiny hill grew in the spot where a giant oak once grew
The roots ripped up, made a hole and earth filled in anew.
Quest97.Clue3:
With the Town Hall just behind,
A large boulder your eyes will find.
Cross the road towards the sign that reads
"Rodney Palmer Environmental Study Area" amidst the weeds.
Quest97.Clue19:
Walk by aging birch trees sprouting hoof-like fungus
Also known as birch polypore mushroom to us.
Mushrooms and fungus are decomposers,
So are worms and microscopic creatures.
Quest97.Clue20:
Beyond the birches only a stone wall remains of the farm from days gone by
Upon this spot a Cornish Farmer's field used to lie
And in New England if the farmer doesn't mow
The life cycles will change and a forest will grow.
Quest97.Clue18:
Stay on the path; don't cross the bridge
No time to get lost on the ridge!
Safety first on Quests or hikes
Don't play on beaver ponds in winter or you might fall through thin ice!
Quest97.Clue1: To get there:  From Route 12A in Cornish, just south of the Cornish-Windsor Covered Bridge, head east on Town House Road. You will pass the Dingleton Covered Bridge and the Blacksmith Covered Bridge, both on your right.
Quest97.Clue17:
From the path see a bridge under which the beaver swim.
But don't jump in!
Look left and see stumps with pointed and chewed tips
Feasted on by beaver teeth and graced by beaver lips.
Quest97.Clue16:
Walk a while to the "seat stump" where you can lunch.
Nearby are musclewood trees the beavers love to munch.
All along the right is a soggy wetland
Born from the stream and the beaver's teeth and hands.

for the confusing new word?

Turn yourself around and go back down

Take a moment, sit on the bleachers, and yield.
Quest107.Clue15:
This pine grove is of the latest succession,
Showing a forest hundreds of years old.
All tall pines were of the ìking's possession,
For building ship mastsî the early settlers were told.
Quest107.Clue10:
To the right a flowering stream you'll find,
Many macroinvertebrates make this their home.
Continue to follow the road and stream as they wind,
But stay on the path and be sure not to roam.

Quest11.Clue5:
Now put your left side to Route 5
And walk til you reach a gravel drive.
You'll see a row of trees.
Go to the fifth one, if you please.
Joseph Alger kept the trees trim,
We have learned a lot about him.
Quest11.Clue17:
It told the trains to go or stop
With red and green lights mounted near to its top.
The station master got telegraph signals that said
When a train would be straight ahead.
Quest11.Title: Fairlee Depot Quest
Quest11.Clue12:
Go to the tracks and walk south 28 ties
There you will find an archeological surprise.
Go a few yards west and dig lightly with your feet
And beneath you will find a slab of concrete.
Quest11.Clue4:
The Green Mountain Boy in 1848
Was the very first train.  It sure was great!
Connecticut & Passumpsic the company's name,
Moving freight and passengers was its game.
Quest11.Clue9:
Now follow the tracks to Bradford (north)
On this Quest by the 3rd and 4th.
After 73 ties, turn west and stay loose
Then walk 'til you reach a line of Spruce.
Quest11.Clue19:
Now that we've given you facts and pleasure,
We will lead you to our Valley Quest treasure.
Go north up the tracks looking to your left side
In a wall made of wood the treasure box will hide!
Quest11.Clue14:
Go to the tracks and walk 46 ties back
To a wide wooden door beside the track.
Luggage was loaded through that rolling door
And steamer trunks piled up, ceiling to floor.
Quest11.Clue3:
Before the railroad came to Fairlee,
People didn't travel merrily:
They had to go by river raft
Or stagecoach on a bumpy path.
Quest11.Clue8:
It was the time of the Great Depression
Which taught our country a great big lesson.
Hobos rode the train from around the U.S.
Joseph gave them food and a place to rest.
They'd go to the river following a path
To shanties that kept out the weather' wrath.
Quest11.Clue16:
Now look for a pole that is tall, wooden and long.
It helped keep things from going wrong.
It use to be a semaphore,
Whose signals prevented a lot of gore.
Quest11.Clue11:
Now retrace your steps to the Depot's front door
Go to its south wall - we'll show you some more.
Quest11.Clue2:
Welcome to the Fairlee Depot Quest!
We'll send you north, east & west.
You'll learn about railroad history
While you seek our treasure-box mystery!
Quest11.Description: Walking through space to mars, you will see stars and martians. There is no comparing the greenness of the aliens, and their work on mars creates an awesome place to explore. Have fun going back in time and changing the past, or seeing the ultimite end of human life from a distance. It's all fun and games when it comes to the this marian trip. This is a fake description
Quest11.Clue7:
Now walk to the tracks keeping the depot on your right
And we'll point out a special site.
Stop at the corner and look to the east
And you'll see where hobos could get a feast.
Quest11.Clue18:
From the semaphore, go north 56 ties,
That's where what's known as the sidetrack lies.
When two trains were coming, one would make the decision
To pull onto the sidetrack--and avoid a collision.
Quest11.Clue13:
This is the floor the old creamery had
Back when dairying in Vermont was really rad!
The creamery sent milk to other places--
To put white moustaches on people's faces!
Quest11.Clue1: To get there: Take I-91 to the Fairlee exit (15).  At the bottom of the off ramp turn east, and then turn left at the T onto Route 5 north. The Quest begins at Ide's Feed Store, just south of the Depot in the heart of Fairlee.
Quest11.Clue6:
He was the master of this station
And made it a wonderful destination.
He planted flowers and vegetables, too,
Displayed fool's gold & mica for travelers through.
Quest11.Clue15:
When campers arrived for Lakes Morey & Fairlee
The trunks all arrived about 10 days early.
Camps' horses came, too, and went wild when they arrived
And would tear down main street from the Depot's drive.
Quest11.Clue10:
Follow the trees along towards the steeple
At the seventh tree, look west, please, people!
Our stationmaster's house was number 1910.
The Depot was Fairlee's town center then.

Go to the bank
and don't get spanked.

Go to the upper edge 
of Flat Rock.
Don't slip and take a dip.

Quest40.Clue4:
Go to the culvert and
try not to take a slide ride.

Go to the middle 
of Flat Rock, Doc.

Go to the steps
but don't get wet.
Quest40.Clue2:
Start where you park.

Go to the big boulder
Beware it's colder.

Go to the pool
and you'll be cool.
Quest40.Title:
Flat Rock Quest
Orford, NH

To get there: From Rte. 10, take 25A for about 4 miles to Quintown Road. Take a right onto Quintown Road and go almost exactly one mile.  Parking is on the left.  The road widens out just a bit to allow for parking.
Quest40.Clue5:
Go to the steps
but don't get wet.

Go back to the bank
duck your shoulder
so you don't hit the boulder.
Under those rocks
you'll find the box.

Quest94.Clue5:
Crossing the bridges and through the trees,
Then to the logs if you please.
Up the rise continuing on,
And follow the trail up and beyond.
Quest94.Title: SCA QUEST
Quest94.Clue12:
The mountains are gone now,
So on to the pines!
Dash down the stone wall from corner to pass,
Go under the archway but not too fast!
Quest94.Clue4:
Walk down the trail, with grass so high,
Letting you still see a slice of sky.
But keep your eye to the right
Or you might get lost far from sight.
Quest94.Clue9:
Now keep walking ye wanderers must do,
On up the rise hoping the sky will stay blue.  
The journey is not yet done,
For there is still some more fun.
Quest94.Clue14:
Come down through the circle,
And back down the path.
You'll come to a stone wall,
You've reached it at last!
Quest94.Clue3:
Welcome to the SCA! 
Look around and you will see
The fire that may escape from thee.
Look straight ahead, down through the trees,
There you can find the water that will please.
Quest94.Clue8:
Across the field, a path there might be.
With sumac adjacent and vines to the right.
Through the tree line the field fades away,
With an image of trees hugging lays at bay.
Quest94.Clue11:
You're almost there, patient you must be.
For the treasure is close, almost close enough to see.
Look up at the mountains just over the pines,
You've come here for the treasure, so don't fall behind.
Quest94.Clue2: Turn right onto Route 12A south. Continue for 6-7 miles. Pass Merriam-Graves on your left, and then pull into the SCA parking lot on the right.
Quest94.Description: Walking through space to mars, you will see stars and martians. There is no comparing the greenness of the aliens, and their work on mars creates an awesome place to explore. Have fun going back in time and changing the past, or seeing the ultimite end of human life from a distance. It's all fun and games when it comes to the this marian trip. This is a fake description
Quest94.Clue7:
Back up the hill your treasure awaits,
Through the opening making haste.
You come to a field now, so yield to your left.
Crossing diagonally I think would be best.
Quest94.Clue13:
So walk through the garden,
On down the path.
Now stop at the signpost,
For the treasure you have passed.
Quest94.Clue1: To get there:  Take I-91 to Exit 8 (Claremont/Ascutney). Follow Routes 11/12/131 East towards New Hampshire. Proceed through several lights, cross the bridge over the Connecticut River
Quest94.Clue6:
A trail on your right, pass it by.
And a tree with mushrooms you will spy.
Through twin trees and up the curve.
Down the hill and left you will swerve.

Here you can stay, both night and day,
What a delight-this camp or picnic site.
Quest94.Clue10:
Follow the snake going on past the tree,
The one that will watch but never will sleep.
Where the bent oak leans o'er the great pine,
Go up on the rise and start your decline.

Quest16.Clue21: Now can you find the Quest box?
Quest16.Clue5:
It used to be called the Phelps Hotel.
The Phelps brothers bought it in 1865.  
They fixed it up with $4,500 worth of California gold.
Quest16.Clue17:
Take another rest and think of 
Success. Look for the sign that has a tree name in it.
Surrounded by maples and birches, 
Follow the path to where you can eat.
{Gazebo Built in 1926}
Quest16.Title: Grafton Town - The Cave Quest
Quest16.Clue12:
Now, to find your next clue, 
 You need to get to the main entrance of the Village park.
 How you do that is up to you, but
We suggest that you find a friendly 
Native and ask for directions.
Quest16.Clue4:
Face this building, turn left and continue up Main St.
On your left will be the biggest building in town.
This is The Old Tavern. It was built in 1801 
and then doubled in size in 1820!
Quest16.Clue9:
Soon you will see a place of prayer.
This brick church was built in 1833.
It used to have sheds behind it 
for church goers to park their horses.
Quest16.Clue19:
Go around the huge rock. Look for the blue
Ribbon on a tree. Then get back on the trail.
Follow the red blazes until you get to the steps.
Quest16.Clue14:
Once you're at the main entrance, 
Walk about six steps and look out ahead 
And slightly to your right.
You should see a path.
Quest16.Clue3:
Built in 1855, it was originally used for the town's post office. 
Write down the first letter on the small rectangular sign
With phone numbers on it.
Quest16.Clue8:
Go through the ball field and past the bleachers and scoreboard.
When you get to the split rail fence on your right, 
Take a right onto the path.
(Make sure you follow rail fence near the rock wall)
Quest16.Clue16:
Passing by 1999 go to the place where you can read
Have a seat and try to succeed
Then on and not up to another room.
Quest16.Clue20:
At last you have made it to the end 
Of the quest. Hope you had fun and
Reaped a lot of good.
Check out the entrance to this natural shelter in front of you.
What shape and letter do you see?
Quest16.Clue11:
There are only two church buildings in town.
Both churches united in 1920 and 
became The Church of Grafton.
Quest16.Clue7:
The next stop on your quest is The Brick Church.
Take Townsend road, which is off Main Street, on the left.
When you get to the Daniels House, go right.
Quest16.Description: Walking through space to mars, you will see stars and martians. There is no comparing the greenness of the aliens, and their work on mars creates an awesome place to explore. Have fun going back in time and changing the past, or seeing the ultimite end of human life from a distance. It's all fun and games when it comes to the this marian trip. This is a fake description
Quest16.Clue2:
Start your quest on Main Street.
It starts two houses west of the bridge 
Go to the building where people go to buy houses.
Quest16.Clue18:
You can sit at the table and cook up a meal. 
For now for our town you will have a feel. 
Here our oldest fire pit rocks 
Are surrounded by beautiful hemlocks.
Quest16.Clue13:
But if you are feeling shy
Circle round the building counter clockwise.
Where bricks end and wood begins
Look for two brick chimneys.
Proceed that-a-way and find the village park.
Quest16.Clue1: To get there: Follow Rt. 121 to Grafton. The Quest begins near the "Old Fire Barn", just west of the bridge and near the intersection of Main St. (121) with Townsend Rd. (35).
Quest16.Clue6:
Go inside to the desk and look up on the wall
for a famous civil war general's  name.
Quest16.Clue15:
Take the path  for a while
(This path could be covered with snow in winter)
You will see red markers soon.
Quest16.Clue10:
People bought the stalls behind the church, 
just like they used to buy the pews inside it.

Quest99.Clue5:
Our bridge is the boss
That you will soon cross
Its continuous strength
Will take you the length
It is a left that you will turn
The rest of the trail you'll earn.
Quest99.Title: Danville Town Forest Quest
Quest99.Clue12:
But before you depart
To the box
You should start
Don't get "stumped"
Look behind one bench
It's there, and
Your quest thirst will be quenched.
Quest99.Clue4:
Near an old pine
Keep going and you'll be fine.
After the last cedar rail
You'll take about twenty-one steps and turn right
The four black cherries will be in sight.
Quest99.Clue9:
When you reach the logging trail
Don't go left or right
Cross it and head up the hill.
After you've reached the top
How many switchbacks have you climbed?
The first one's not so bad
The second is the worst
Stop on the third and quench your thirst.
Quest99.Clue3:
It's at this walkway
Where you begin
Stay between the parallel poles
And they will lead you within.
Though it's a road
It's really our trail
At the first bend there's an apple tree
Quest99.Clue8:
As you walk along enjoying the serenity
Stop to take a look above triangle tree
You will hear the sound of the burbling brook
Barbed wire, at the stone wall you take a look.
The skylight above will light your way
Even if it's a cloudy day.
At the end of our section notice the mushroom shelves
Maybe if you're quick you'll see some elves.
Quest99.Clue11:
Nearing a fork
Stay to the left
Take a deep breath 
It's almost time to rest.
You're at the top
You're climbing's been completed
The fun's not over
More hiking is needed.
Quest99.Clue2: Turn left on Access Road-look for the "Town Forest" sign.  Travel 0.2 mi. on the single lane, dirt Access Rd. to the clearing.  Park in the lot there. The Quest begins at the brochure box.
Quest99.Description: Walking through space to mars, you will see stars and martians. There is no comparing the greenness of the aliens, and their work on mars creates an awesome place to explore. Have fun going back in time and changing the past, or seeing the ultimite end of human life from a distance. It's all fun and games when it comes to the this marian trip. This is a fake description
Quest99.Clue7:
Welcome to the next section
Don't fall down the ridge
For soon you'll be crossing 
our primitive bridge
Beeches
Birches
Bugs 
And Brooks
They're the essence of our trail's look.
Quest99.Clue13:
Descending the hill will be a test
The first step should be to the west
Follow the trail
According to the wood
At the end of the maple grove
Look ahead to the arrow
For ahead the trail should get less narrow
You're on your way down the logging road 
Back to cars and headed for home.
Quest99.Clue1: To Get There:  From the blinking light in Danville, take Route 2 east for 1.1 miles.  Turn right on Penny Lane and travel 2.8 miles.
Quest99.Clue6:
Along the road
Then left to woods
Like in a dream
You'll follow our stream
Alas from our sylvan dream
You must leave
Just before you go
Take pause and deeply breathe.
Quest99.Clue10:
You're getting closer to the top
And just before you do
Notice all the hemlock stumps
On either side of you.
Exit our woods into a clearing
At the stump,
Left,
You'll be steering.

Quest104.Clue21:
See?  Now you've come back to the flat place,
Where canoes and potties you should face.
Back in your vessel, or explore some more . . .
We hope this island Quest wasn't a bore!
Quest104.Clue5:
You will also know that you are getting quite near
If a free-standing potty of blue does appear.
Around the bend now, keep to the right,
'Til a tiny island of birch is in sight.
Quest104.Clue17:
'Round a bend, up a hill, keep walking to find
A green-painted table of the picnicky kind.
It should be sitting quite close to a circle of stone,
You have now arrived in the Quest box zone!
Quest104.Title: Gilman Island Quest
Quest104.Clue12:
Now Ledyard had cabins on these islands three,
But when the water got high they could no longer be.
So the club rented land from New England Power
On this island, called "Gilman," that used to be "Nicker."
Quest104.Clue4:
At the tip of this isle, take a left toward the tree
That hangs out o'er the water for all to come see.
Up ahead, to your right, a spot you should spy,
Where the land is as flat as a big pizza pie.
Quest104.Clue9:
If you follow the orange, you'll come to a cabin,
Built in honor of a past Marine Corps captain.
T'was John Abbot Titcomb, class of 1932,
Killed fighting bravely during World War II.
Quest104.Clue19:
The logs are all rotting, just lying around, 
But look to the stump that still stands in the ground.
At the stump's base, please carefully seek-
Out from a birch "sleeve" the box should peek.
Quest104.Clue14:
Behind the cabin, there's a rock with a blaze,
So carefully climb to the top to continue this maze.
You'll observe that the trail has changed just a bit.
The land is more rugged; make sure you don't trip!
Quest104.Clue3:
Past the bridge, you should keep going straight,
To the right is an arch; many divers can relate.
Further on to your left you should see a sewage place,
So just row a bit more and this island you'll face.
Quest104.Clue8:
Meander along-keep the shore on your right
(A wander off-trail might cause a fright).
The blazes are there, just keep following them 'round,
But do be careful of rocks and stumps on the ground.
Quest104.Clue16:
When you reach a fire pit, the trails splits here,
So keep to the LEFT for your treasure so dear.
Continue along, seeking orange tree paint,
If the water is still to your right, then you are a saint.
Quest104.Clue20:
Sign in, collect the stamp, and place it carefully back
For other clever Questers who are on the right track.
To get back to your boat, get back on the trail,
And keep following the blazes 'round-you won't fail.
Quest104.Clue11:
The water upstream was raised 15 feet,
Submerging three islands whole-what a feat!
Chase, Occum, and Johnny Johnson were their names,
Now these islands exist only in fame.
Quest104.Clue7:
Now climb from your vessel and head into the woods,
You'll want to head RIGHT for your treasure box goods.
Now look to the trees where you'll see orange marks,
On or replacing what once was their bark.
Quest104.Description: Walking through space to mars, you will see stars and martians. There is no comparing the greenness of the aliens, and their work on mars creates an awesome place to explore. Have fun going back in time and changing the past, or seeing the ultimite end of human life from a distance. It's all fun and games when it comes to the this marian trip. This is a fake description
Quest104.Clue2:
Head from the docks and the house for canoes,
Paddle toward the bridge upon this water so blue.
This river and valley are older than you know,
Formed by a glacial lake oh so many years ago.
Quest104.Clue18:
Sit at the table with your back to the fire,
Look straight ahead-a dead birch you desire.
The water should be to your right and behind, 
Now 25 paces 'til the dead birch you find.
Quest104.Clue13:
Since Ledyard Canoe Club had cabins no longer,
This one you see here was built to be stronger
(and higher above that dam's water line
that swallowed up those others so fine).
Quest104.Clue1: To Get There:  This Quest begins at the Ledyard Canoe Club (LCC).  LCC is located at the north end of the parking lot on the east (Hanover) side of the Ledyard Bridge.  Please note: You will need a canoe or kayak to complete this Quest!  They can be rented at the LCC.
Quest104.Clue6:
At this point in your paddle, you have come to a beach
Where a "Canoe Rest AreaóNew England Power" sign is in reach.
"Park" your canoe on the sand, and tie it up tight,
Or you will be swimming back home tonight.
Quest104.Clue15:
Along the isle's ridge, like an explorer you walk,
Keep marching along, keep an eye on the clock.
This may take a while, be patient my friend,
And remember to enjoy this Quest 'til the end.
Quest104.Clue10:
This lovely log cabin was built in '52,
But WHY? Give a listen and I'll tell you...
The Wilder Dam is found just downstream,
When it was built it caused quite a scene.
